overview: This subject explores skills required for transport planners who wish to improve the economic, environmental and social performance of urban transport systems. It draws on international experience and research to articulate the principles and practical techniques in two key areas:
Public transport planning and network design; and
The preparation of regional multi-modal transport plans.

This subject includes a half-day field trip involving use of public transport services in a chosen suburban region of Melbourne. This trip will be undertaken in small groups in week 3 and is a hurdle requirement. Students will require a valid Myki card, and the cost will not exceed a daily ticket in Zone 1.
intended learning outcomes: Examine and describe the potential for public transport networks in the suburbs of dispersed cities
Explain the historical context of current regional transport plans, policies and institutional arrangements in Melbourne and Vancouver
Evaluate and critically analyse existing public transport operational patterns in Australian and international contexts
Synthesise theoretical concepts, ideas and modern arguments in public transport planning
Apply network-planning principles to the development of a multi-modal transport plan

additional pre-requisite: Admission into a course at the Melbourne School of Design
Selection of the Transport specialisation (formal) in the MC-CIVENG Master of Civil Engineering

assessments.description: A supply and demand analysis of a community's public transport network .. 1250 words (each)
A public transport network strategy. 2500 words
Participation via regular engagement with online discussion board and submission of reading notes. 500 words

Semester 2.Contact hours: 36 (1X1 hour lecture   and 1X2 hour tutorial per week)
